section.name: Table of Contents
section.p: Note: Java 1.5 annotation support is not implemented in the 1.0-beta1 release.
But what we have is an API that will make the migration minimal and will allow both annotation schemes to co-exist seamlessly.
We will have it implemented for the 1.0-beta2 release, so stay tuned.

section.name: Matching on Annotations
section.p: AspectWerkz supports matching on annotations. This means that you can define your pointcuts to pick out join points that is annotated with a certain annotation.
The matching will work equally good with JavaDoc-style annotations or a Java 1.5 annotations.

section.name: Annotation Proxies
section.p: To be make the migration phase from JavaDoc-style to Java 1.5 annotations as smooth as possible AspectWerkz has implemented a concept of Annotation Proxies.

This proxy concept also makes it possible to achive strong typing even for JavaDoc-style annotations. Errors are reported already in the compilation phase. This is much safer than most JavaDoc annotation implementations available, since those are weakly typed, string based solutions.
An annotation proxy is a proxy class with a field for each key:value pair in the annotation.

As you can see, the proxy extends the AnnotationProxyBase class. Then there is a getter method with the exact same name as the name for the parameter and a setter method which has the name prefixed with set.
The getter methods will be used by you to retrieve the data and the setter methods are used by the framework to set the data in the proxy.
This proxy does now work equally good with JavaDoc style annotations and Java 1.5 style annotations.

subsection.name: Strongly typed Annotations
subsection.p: All annotations are strongly typed. Both JavaDoc-style and Java 1.5 style annotations.

We currently support the following type of named parameters:
primitives
- name1=8366 name2=86.2345D name3=true name4='\n'
strings
- name="blablabla"
arrays
- name={"Hello", "World"} or name={46.34F, 836.45F}
references to static fields
- name=org.foo.Bar.SOME_CONSTANT
nested annotations
- TO BE IMPLEMENTED

You can also define just one single anonymous value for the annotation. This value will then be set by the framework through the method called void setvalue(String value). So in order for this to work the parameter must be a String (a current limitation, might change later) and add the method to the proxy class. This maps to the Java 1.5 simple value idea.

section.name: Compiling Annotations - JavaDoc style annotations
section.p: If you are using custom JavaDoc-style annotations then you have to compile in into bytecode of the classes. This is done with the AnnotationC compiler. Please note that this is not needed for Java 1.5 annotations.
You can run AnnotationC from the command line. (It might be useful to run the ASPECTWERKZ_HOME/bin/setEnv.{bat|sh} script first.)

You invoke the compiler like this:
java [options...] org.codehaus.aspectwerkz.annotation.AnnotationC [-verbose] -src <path to src dir> -classes <path to classes dir> [-dest <path to destination dir>] [-custom <property file for custom annotations>]
The last option -custom property_file_for_custom_annotations points to the a property file which defines the annotations by mapping the names to the proxy implementations.

Example of an annotation properties file:
ReadOnly = test.expression.ReadOnlyAnnotationProxy Requires = test.expression.RequiresAnnotationProxy Serializable = test.expression.SerializableAnnotationProxy
In which f.e. Requires is the @Requries annotation
For Java 1.5 annotations you would have to specify the fully qualified name of the annotation interface as the name.

section.name: Runtime retrieval of Annotations
section.p: You can retrieve the annotations at runtime using the Annotations class.
